You're taking it all too seriously. What I find is that the better writers who have done high-end writing, or are seriously educated, tend to not be able to dumb themselves down to content mill level. I was one of those for a long time, fighting to increase the standards of content mill work. Now I just crank it out. Seriously, like /u/workathomewriter says, it's mostly just rewriting the first good link you find.
After doing this for 9 years, I would never submit a free article to a website in an application. That just screams scam right there. They probably take those 2,000 word articles, break them up into 4 or 5 shorter articles and sell them for $50 apiece to their clients.
And you just wasted a lot of time writing this long post. If you're going to make it in content mill world, I'd say you are going to have to understand what they are and how to make money on them at 3 to 5 CPW. You have to learn to crank out work quickly, and screw the quality. They want stuff written to an 8th grade level.
If you take yourself and your writing this seriously, I'd suggest writing on spec at Constant Content where you can charge whatever you want, but first, read a few online articles from not-so-intellectual sites so you can learn that what most website owners (99% of whom are affiliate marketers) want is crap. Cheap crap with keywords that make them money. Trying to produce quality work is a waste of time, and intellectualizing content mill writing is a waste of your brain.

ADDICTION isn't a choice, but whether you give in to it is a choice. Some people are strong enough to fight it, some aren't. I've been to AA meetings, in fact, I was a member of Al-Anon for 30 years. Some people choose to not give in to the addiction, some choose to stay addicted. I didn't say it was an easy choice, but it's still a choice. When you're sitting there with that bottle of beer or shot of liquor in your hand, it's your choice whether to drink it. Your body may be saying you "need" it, but it's still your choice. It also depends on what they are writing. Technical writing pays way more, and marketing copy pays way more. I have a friend who writes sales copy and she makes six figures working basically 20-30 hours a week. Of course, you have to be really good and get results. I know SEO writers who can draw in traffic like mad who make almost as much.
Of course, there are also those who, like you, consider 10 CPW "a good rate" and will never ask for more. Let me just give you one example of how asking for what you are worth can work. One friend was working through a bidding site for 2 CPW writing quick little 400 words articles. She decided that wasn't enough, so she told the client she could no longer write them, because she was raising her rate to 5 CPW. He immedately told her he would pay her price, and not much later raised it to 7 CPW. When she finally did quit because she just couldn't think of anything else to write on the topic, he told her his budget was 10 CPW. If she had asked for 10 CPW when she raised her rates the first time, he would have paid it.
The thing about asking for what you are worth is that you will have to bid more or market yourself more or try harder to get jobs, but it's like every other job. There are fewer employers paying that rate, but it's worth holding out.
The key is not to tell anyone you are working for less to keep the lights on. Clients know that. They aren't stupid, but they also know that they get what they pay for. Some don't care about quality, just traffic. They open hundreds of crap sites and stick up crap copy loaded with keywords and ads. They work in volume. Then there are those clients who create quality sites and want quality copy. They are looking for expert status. These are the ones you want to work for.

Maybe so. Maybe I'm wrong. I'm just stating how I feel about the entire scenario. I don't have solutions. I'll give you an analogy I can understand, though. It's like killing insects in your garden. If you look at a plant and see a whole lot of aphids and a whole lot of red and black bugs, you'd think you need to get rid of them all. The truth is, the red and black bugs are probably ladybug larvae that are eating the aphids. Kill them all and the aphids come back, but now there are no ladybug larvae to eat them, so they kill the plants. It's hard to tell the good from the bad sometimes. Say there is a vet who is also addicted to painkillers because of injuries he received overseas during a war. Do you lump him in with all the street junkies who just like to get high simply because he's an addict?
Also, in my scenario (and this is something I have considered) a shitton of Native Americans would not get health care because of alcohol and drug addiction, so catch 22.

I do. My genes make me an addict. Right now, I'm addicted to sugar. I ate a whole bag of jelly beans yesterday, telling myself the whole time to throw them out and not eat them. No, it's not liquor or heroin, but it's just as much an addiction, and I fight it every day. I am also addicted to the internet. When the web goes down, as it sometimes does, I go insane. I mean really insane. I can't stand the thought of being disconnected. I'm also addicted to gardening. I can't stop. I used to be so bad when I had more space that I would end up giving away literal pickup truck loads of plants, and still had too many. I'm also addicted to television, to the detriment of my work life. I work at home, and I have not made a single penny in the past week because of watching t.v. and being on reddit. Now Sense8's new season just came out, and I will spend my entire weekend watching it. I can't stop. I try to, but I can't.
I get just as high from these things as you do from drugs or alcohol or whatever you are addicted to, and they all affect my life and relationships negatively, but I can't stop. I count myself blessed that I'm not addicted to alcohol and drugs like everyone else in my family -- or food, like my nephew, who died from pancreatic cancer from diabetes caused by his weight, which was over 400 lbs., but I still know what it's like to get up every day and VOW to myself that "today, I'm going to work. I'm not going to watch t.v." and then fail at that over and over and over. I swear to myself every day I'm not going on reddit, but I do over and over and over. I swear to myself I'm not eating sugar, and I do over and over and over. Sometimes I feel so out of control and helpless, so yes, I do understand addiction. My husband was a drug addict and alcoholic. I watched him struggle. I watched my mother and father struggle. I walked away from my alcoholic drug-addicted sister because I couldn't stand to see one more person die from that disease.
Will my addictions kill me? Maybe the sugar addiction. My grandmother, who didn't drink, died of liver cancer. The doctor said it was from eating too much sugar. You see, it isn't the alcohol that kills your liver. Your body burns that off very quickly. It's the sugar.

To be totally honest here, without purposely sounding insensitive, I happen to know that people can get on disability due to the damage that something like alcoholism or drug addiction has done to their bodies, and a great many of them use those disability checks to carry on with their bad habits. I know addiction is a disease (grew up in an alcoholic family), but it's a disease you have control over if you want to. You don't have to drink or do drugs. I know the compulsion is strong, and it's a tough choice, but when it comes down to it, it's still a choice. My entire family are alcoholics, but I'm not. I have every bad gene they ever could have passed down but I CHOSE not to drink to excess and I CHOSE not to smoke myself to an early grave like a lot of my relatives did. I CHOSE not to eat like a pig and end up at 300 lbs. dying of heart disease. I've never understood why the government rewards bad behavior. I'm not stupid. I know all the excuses these people give and I know that I sound insensitive to some people, but if I'm going to be a fucking asshole, it will be to someone who made the choice to ruin their body and not to a child who is born with a bad heart or some other disease, or someone who has diseases commonly associated with aging, such as arthritis or heart and lung problems, that were NOT caused by an irresponsible lifestyle. There has to be a line somewhere that needs to be solid and bright and that people are aware that crossing it may cause you to have no medical care if you proceed to ruin your body. If you are a finance expert, you should be able to get much more than 10 CPW on a regular basis. I have a CPA friend who won't write articles on high finance for less than 20 CPW. If you don't have a degree or credentials, it might be harder.
I do agree with finding micro-niches within the finance niche. For example, there is a huge audience for permaculture that is rapidly growing. A lot of those people are looking to make money at it, so you could write cost analysis of permaculture farming vs. conventional farming, or articles on how to get approved to buy property for permaculture (for some reason, banks don't like this idea, but they'll loan to conventional farms). I'd aim those articles at bankers, outlining why it would be beneficial for them to loan to permaculture operations.
Niches like solar and wind power also need cost/benefit analysis articles. If someone is planning to put up solar on their house, for instance, how much will they be able to recoup if they have to sell, or how much over time will the setup pay for itself? While a lot of this info is out there, it's mostly dated, so updated stats would be valuable to someone.
I'm not sure infographics would be so great on a gardening blog, besides, they seem spammy and hard to understand to me many times. I'll keep it in mind, though.

WRITING.TITLE: I'm ready to take the leap. Need a tiny bit of advice about Amazon and eBay affiliates
WRITING.TEXT:
I have a gardening blog, and I'm going to start putting affiliate ads on it. I have Adsense up, and I'm an Amazon and eBay affiliate, so I'm going to start there, then search for better ones. I get about 3,000 visits a month, which I know isn't much.
Mostly, I've been posting about personal gardening with a few how-to posts. I'm going to start doing many more how-to posts and some plant profiles as well. I'm in Florida, so it's already a niche blog, since we have such strange gardening down here (we literally are gardening the same time as Aussies).
I also want to tie in some outdoor living and design content, so I can pitch higher priced items.
Does anyone have any tips on using Amazon and eBay, or even how to get better paying adsense ads? A link to a site or book recommendation would be fine too, although I've read so many affiliate marketing books, I feel like I"m in overload.
TIA
It's against the Amazon TOU to do this. You should take this post down before someone turns you in.

Since you're working digitally, you don't really need to be in the city to work. There are people who work digitally while traveling all over the world. Just start finding lawyers who don't have a blog or who have a neglected blog and write to them, asking if they would be interested in having you update or maintain it, or just to buy some articles for it. That's why I said set up a writer's website, so you could have something to show them. Check out some legal sites to get an idea of what kind of content they have, and use that as a guide to write your articles.
I write for people all over the world, even in the U.K. I have a client who lives in Wales and one who lives in Australia. I'm in the U.S.
I don't have a car.
Well, so far, my stuff has funded 5 moves, so why not? LOL
I have lupus, so I can't do trail walking in the heat at all, and I definitely can't carry a pack, but thanks for the suggestion. I usually go trail walking in the fall and winter.

You like to write, and there are always people looking for legal writers for their websites. I propose you put up a writer's site and start trying to find jobs doing that. I know of at least one former lawyer who makes a lot of money writing legal articles on lawyer websites. It's not exactly what you want, but it's using your education to get something you want.

I think that most of them pay through PayPal, and you have to be 18 to have a PayPal account, so that's a problem. There are jobs on Ratracerebellion.com that hire 16 yos, but you have to be able to get paid.

Forgot to mention that once you find your work, most times sending a letter to her telling her to take it down or you will send a DMCA report to Google (mention that she may lose her adsense if she has it), her webhost and her domain provider usually works to get it taken down. Then you have to write to Google and ask them to remove it from search, so you can put it up or resell it without it being flagged as duplicate content. ETA: Also, mention that you will be posting her name and information all over social media, and also report her to LinkedIn.
Good luck! It's a lot of work, but once you have all this set up in form letters, it takes less than an hour overall to do.

I just want one big adventure before I die. I didn't get to have my adventures when I was young, because I was raising two kids on my own, so it was work, work, work. People called me a homebody, but the truth was, I was just so broke I couldn't afford to do anything but stay home and putz around in my house and garden. I don't have a lot of money, but I do have my SS and I work online, so I can supplement. I'm not taking off tomorrow, because I want to have some savings in place first, but I figure if I work very hard for a year, I can do something besides sit here and be unhappy. I'll never know until I try.
Yeah, been reading there for awhile. I don't know if that's the life for me, but it is enticing.
Thanks. That's nice to know.

I hope you kept a copy of your work that is date stamped. Do a Copyscape search immediately to find out if she used the work. Look to see if she has Adsense on her site. If so, file a DMCA complaint with Google asking them to have her remove the stolen content. It's either that, or she will lose her adsense.
Also, search whois.net to find out who her domain provider is. Put a DMCA complaint in to them as well, saying she is using their domain for plagiarized copy. It may do nothing, but you can also find out who her webhost is and write to them.
I have all these letters set up on my computer, and I do not hesitate to use them if and when someone steals my work. You can find DMCA letters to use all over the web.

WRITING.TITLE: My life is still too complicated
WRITING.TEXT:
I've changed my life completely in the past 9 years; went from a corporate retail job to being a freelance writer, moved from a 3/2/1 house to eventually this 520 sf apartment. I went from 1/4 acre lot to about 250 sf of garden space. I no longer own a car, so walk, bus and ride a bike (hadn't been on one in 20 years before this) everywhere. I spend less then $200 a month for food most months. I have very, very few clothes (down from two closets full previously), one good pair of jeans, and one good pair of walking shoes.
Yesterday, I got tired of washing eating utensils, so I put away all but 2 of everything except I kept out 9 spoons, because that's mostly what I eat with. I don't really need 9 spoons, but I don't want to have to keep washing them all day, so 9 it is.
I share a small community garden plot close by, and I've gotten to where I hate going there, because it's just one more chore I have to do. I had huge plans for planting my courtyard but instead, I've decided to lay out an area for a few favorite plants, then fill the rest in with mulch because it's just something I have no interest in anymore.
I sometimes pick up things I think I'll eventually need or can use from beside the apartment dumpsters, but lately, I've been taking dumpster finds back out to the dumpster, because I want space more than I want stuff.
I think a lot about getting rid of it all and going to live in a van, traveling around the country, because I've never really seen the U.S. due to no money to travel. I don't know how long I could do that, but every time I have to do a deep clean of the apartment because it's gotten a little out of hand, I think how nice it must be only to have a tiny little van full of the essentials of life. Just now, while I was watering my indoor plants, I thought "I should just give all of these away. What good are they to me, really?" Plants and gardening used to be my life, and now it just seems like work.
It's all just so much to take care of! My neighbor was shocked I don't have a washer and dryer, and I told her it's just one more thing to break and have to get fixed. She didn't understand how I can stand going to the laundry room to do my laundry, but I explained to her that I have so few clothes and linens now that I can do it all in two loads once a week. I wish I could do it in one. If I lived in a van, I could do it in one.
I look at everything in here every day and think "I don't need this or that or that or ..." you get the idea. I have 5 frying pans. Who the hell needs 5 frying pans? I used to love my things, and to a point, I still do, but more and more, they are just things to take care of and things that require space that I don't want to clean and take care of. If I didn't have all these things, I wouldn't need all this space.
Am I going insane, or does anyone else feel this way?

I moved 5 times in 5 years. I have gone from a 3/2/1 house on 1/4 acre, with one room and a garage I could not walk into, to this 520sf apartment with a small courtyard. I have sold, given away, had stolen, or just left behind things in every place I lived (except a temporary 3-month rental while I looked for a place.) I still can't sleep in my BR because it is piled with boxes -- and I do mean piled. The room is 14 x 11, and I literally have a pile of boxes in about an 8x10 ft area almost up to the ceiling, and I've been here 2 years in July. I guess you can say it's taken me 7 years to get to this point, and I'm determined to be in that bedroom with NO boxes outside of closets by Christmas.
Sometimes, I think of the things I no longer own and I don't have a clue why I thought I needed them. I only miss one thing -- my grandmother's wool blanket which was stolen from me, which I inherited when she died when I was 15 years old. That still makes me furious to this day, that someone would steal that from me, and I know who did it too, but can't prove it, because she took it somewhere and hid it. She stole a lot of things from me. That's the only thing I miss.
Right now, when I go through boxes, I look at things and say "Am I going to use this in the next year?" Some of those things in that room have been packed up since 1996. Some of them are important, but mostly, I don't even know what is in all those boxes. I carried around boxes of Christmas lights and ornaments for years, even though I stopped celebrating Christmas 15 years ago. I have no idea why. I don't know if I still have those boxes, but if I do, they will all be donated.
I guess the point of all this is that the further you get into the process, the more you realize that you don't need. I stare at a bookshelf full of books in my LR every day and think that I really should just give all those books away. I'm never going to read them again. I don't know why I kept these particular books when I got rid of hundreds of others, but here they are, and they are going to be pared down drastically very soon.
It's a process. Some do it quickly so they won't change their minds. Some give thought and consideration to every single item. You do you. We can't tell you how that should work.
These don't seem to matter to anybody anymore.

On the upside, if they do this, they will lose a lot of their base and we have a better chance to get congress back in 2018.

REMEMBER: Everything in real estate has to be in writing, so if you call your landlord, follow up with a written confirmation of the conversation. You'll have to have that if things don't work out and you need to break your lease.

Look at your lease. It should have a clause stating how many people can live in the aparment. I rented a 2-BR house and it said only 4 unrelated people and 5 people overall. You have a long way to go to get to $4,000 a month. Most of the better mills are not accepting applications right now. Yes, there are people making good money on Textbroker, but most of them have specialized degrees or have been there for years and have many private clients they write for. I've been there 5 years, and have never had a private client. I don't work there much, because I have better options now, but it's not a place to get rich quick, by any means.
Do you know how to write in AP style? If not, learn it quickly, because all the mills use it, and some are very strict about it. Textbroker has a comma fetish, and they will demote you over comma issues.
In short, freelance writing is not a "I don't want to work a regular job, so I'm going to freelance" income. Most people started out part-time and worked thier way up before they could quit their jobs. Not trying to be mean, just telling you the absolute God's honest truth. I see so many people in here who have bought the hype that freelance writing is a gold mine, but unless you have some sort of specialized degree like law or tech or finance, or you have experience writing in those verticals, you aren't going to make a full-tme salary up front without working 60 hour weeks.

There are so many factors. Some topics pay better than others, your experience counts (don't expect to start at 20cpw unless you have a degree in journalism and a couple of years of experience). I make most of my money right now writing product descriptions because online articles are not as hot as e-commerce. You have to be fast to make decent money at it. I've been doing it awhile, so I can make about $20 an hour if there is plenty of work and I can get on a roll, but some days I've only made $10, and that's not for 8 hours straight. It doesn't work that way.
Freelance writing is feast or famine, and you have to be very flexible in what you are willing to write. If you're looking for something stable, this isn't it, although there are some people who have turned it into a decent living.
There is no way to project what you can make down the road, because the market changes every day. I'm not writing now what I wrote when I started, nor am I earning what I used to earn. Remember also, that you will be self-employed, so you have to pay your own taxes. I don't know about Canada, but in the U.S., we save back about 30% of each payout for taxes.
Why don't you get started somewhere like one of the content mills and see how you like it? Textbroker has a site for the UK (textbroker.co.uk) and it's as good a place to start as any. They don't pay the best, but you can learn what clients want there, and work your way up to better pay and direct orders. If you hate it, you can go on to something else.

WRITING.TITLE: How am I supposed to declutter when people keep moving and tossing out good stuff?
WRITING.TEXT:
Actually, some of the stuff I got will help me declutter, like the nice bookshelves and tables. I now have somewhere to put things I take out of the boxes. Honestly, I figure I can unload about 10-12 boxes onto this huge bookshelf, which motivates me to unpack them and get rid of more stuff.
The outdoor tables will help get my plants up off the ground so I can sort and photograph them to sell.
But I really didn't need that microwave! Here I am thinking of getting rid of the one I have, and now I have TWO! This one is a bit nicer, a bit smaller and works perfectly, so I guess I'll keep it for now and get rid of the other one. It's not worth selling because the ring under the glass is broken, but if I toss it up on Craigslist for free, maybe someone will take it.
I also got one of those tension-bar bath organizers, which I really, really need. That will get things off the sink counter and the top of the toilet tank.
Now, if I could just find a place to put them until I can get them where they need to be.
That says nothing about scheduling. If you tell them you can only do 10 hours per week, it seems like they will only assign you 10 hours of work.

I'm with you! I've had a horrendous few years where most of what I own has been packed in unopened boxes for 5 years. No way am I just tossing that stuff out!
I actually had someone say "Why go through it all? Just load up the boxes and take them to Goodwill since you don't even know what's in them?" Really??? The fact that I don't know what's in them is EXACTLY why I have to go through them.
I had pared down to things I didn't think I could or didn't want to live without, so everything in those boxes is something in those categories.
I have been in this apartment almost two years now. The first year, I was so scared I was going to have to move again, I wouldn't unpack anything but what I really needed. I even kept all my boxes, flattened out, just in case. For most of the next year, I was helping my son financially during his last year of college, and couldn't afford to furnish the place like I wanted, so I just put it off. Now that all that is out of the way, I get to go through my treasures and decide what I really want to keep and what I can let go of.
Don't feel bad at all! Other people don't know you and don't know your life or your heart. Do what gives you JOY!

There is no excuse for being rude to customers, especially not talking about them behind their backs.

WRITING.TITLE: Copper Bowls

WRITING.TITLE: Working Online is Not Overnight Money
WRITING.TEXT:
I see so many people on here asking for quick money that they need in a very few days. You'd have better luck selling your possessions.
Setting up accounts takes time, and if you are under 18 and don't have a PayPal account, you're pretty much screwed. MTurk pays into Amazon Payments, which you need to transfer to either a prepaid debit card or a bank account.
The problem with places like UpWork is that it takes longer than a few days sometimes just to get a reply from some jobs, and even longer than that to get the jobs approved and paid.
So if you have any inkling that you may need money in the future very quickly, set things up now. Otherwise, start going through everything you own and sell it on Craigslist.
I speak from experience. I've been working online for 8 years, mostly writing, and I only have two places where I could work and make any amount of money paid overnight or in a few days, and that would be limited by how much competition there is for that work and how much work there is available. One of those is MTurk and one is not accepting applications, so no need to write and ask me what they are.
5 days is hard. Most places take that long to verify your account. You can try MTurk, but you'd need a bank account or prepaid debit card to transfer the Amazon Payments money into.

Better in some ways, worse in others. Search engines grade you not only on how long people stay on a page, but overall on how long they stay on the site, how many links they click and how many pages they visit. I'd say never put over 1200 words on one page without breaking it up in some way, although some say no more than 800 and some say up to 1500.
ETA There is something called a "bounce rate" that measures visitors who click in and quickly back out. If you have a long article, some visitors will click quickly back out because they don't want to read it all. I've done that too.
You may have to experiment, based on your topic. You are also graded on return visitors, so in my example, someone may leave after reading about varieties of blueberries, then when they get one, will come back to read about how to plant and grow them, then if they get pests will remember the site and come back to learn about how to control pests. This doesn't work for every topic, but it's a pretty standard way to get a higher ranking.
No, I just heard it as a rumor, sorry. I don't feel like it would benefit them much, but Bezos seems to have gone batshit crazy lately, so who knows?

Someone once told me to always go for higher priced items on Amazon and impulse items on Clickbank. I haven't done anything on Clickbank because they annoyed me with all their spam.
The way I work Amazon is to write a product review and link to the Amazon product in a line that says "This is the best price I could find online for this product." People love bargains, and they by-and-large don't like to do a lot of comparison shopping. I also relate other items to the item I'm reviewing, like with diatomaceous earth for internal use, I will point out that while DE removes dangerous heavy metals, it also removes essential minerals that are metals, such as iron, zinc and copper, so I link to those supplements. To get them to buy a larger size, I point out that it is also useful in the home or garden to kill insect pests.
Yes, Amazon commissions are painfully low, and there are rumors they are discontinuing their affiliate program soon, but if you "stack" products like I do, and link to the higher-priced items, you'll make more sales. You need to tell people WHY they should buy an item, not just throw up a link.

Professional blogger/writer here. Most people only have the attention span to read about 600 words at a time, so put your most important material in the first 600 words if you're wanting to give information. By breaking up long articles in to pages, or even serial blog posts (part 1, part 2, or even different related topics) the mind does a "reset" every time it reaches another page, and starts again on the 600 word limit. Still, after a number of pages, the mind may have all the information it needs, and just not read the rest. This is why it's important to "front load" the most important info into the first part of an article.
For example, I once wrote a series of articles on blueberries. I could have put it all into one large article, but instead, I broke it down into four 600-word articles on choosing a type and variety, how to plant, how to care for them and pests and diseases. I did this because some people are only looking for one of those topics and don't want to scroll through a 3,000 word articles to find the info. If they can't find what they want quickly, they'll click out and go elsewhere.
On a blog, how long a person stays on the site is just as important as the fact that they click on your search link. You don't want drive-bys, so you give things to them in bites with internal links leading to other bites.
As a professional writer, I think conciseness is the most important thing to learn. Say as much as you can in as few words as possible. I start out free writing, just letting thoughts flow, then I go back and tighten up the copy at least twice, also reading for spelling and grammar. Breaking long articles up into smaller, concise bites will help keep people on your blog longer.
Don't fall for that. Lyricists make big money. If you are really good, get an agent and register yourself as a lyricist.

Only once did I have a person refuse to correct the piece or remove the byline, so I did a total rewrite of the piece on my own blog, corrected the errors, and noted that it had been made factually incorrect by an editor and the client refused to remove my name, so I wanted to correct the errors. He didn't seem to see the difference in complexity, but there was enough so that half of the class was failing, and the curve was outrageous. No one got an A and only one boy got a B. I failed or just passed every test, and finally just stopped doing them at all, just put my name on them and turned them in. I made a C for the course. That's how big the curve was.

Save that article and sell it elsewhere, but FIRST run it through copyscape for a week to make sure he hasn't published it. That is a common scam on some sites to post a long article with great pay, then reject it and publish anyway, in effect stealing your work. If it's been stolen, go the DMCA route first. If that doesn't work, find out who his hosting provider is and turn him in for plagiarism. If he has ads on his page, go to them and tell them he is a plagiarist and ask them to remove their ads from that site. If he has Adsense, Google has a form you can fill out. I've had to do this a few times, but I don't just do like most people do and walk away. I go after them big time.

WRITING.TITLE: I run a business....take me seriously, dammit!
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm so sick of people acting like freelance writing is some hobby that people do for the fun of it. I've turned down three jobs in the last month because they refused to sign a contract. I try to explain that I'm a business person, that this is my business, but for some reason, the word "freelance" makes them not take me seriously. I actually had one say "Oh, I thought you were freelance." I wanted to say "Do you have a dictionary?" I guess I'm just supposed to trust them to pay me when they say they will, right? Wrong.
I've also been trying to hire someone to write some blog articles for me. I asked for a resume. One said "I don't want to send a resume, I work under a pseudonym." WHAT??? I blame this on the PayPal rule that if you don't make $20,000 a year or have 200 transactions, you don't get a 1099. Evidently, everyone just wants to work under the table and not pay taxes. Do they not realize that the IRS can find out that you're doing this? Heard about someone last year who got audited by the IRS and they made him give them all his PayPal statements for the year. Found out he had only reported half his freelance income, and now he's in deep doo-doo.
One said "What do you need a resume for?" I just didn't even answer.
I work so hard for my money, and I run my business like any other sole proprietorship, which means I need a contract and I need resumes and I need you to act like you would if you were applying at a brick-and-mortar business. You surely wouldn't walk into a store and say "I need you to hire me, but I don't want to fill out an application or even give you my name and I want to work only under the table."
I know Reddit has a lot of really young people on it, but this is ridiculous! If you want a job, act like a grown up living in a grown-up world.

Been there, done that. Bubblews, Mahalo, Examiner, Bright Hub...need I go on? Anyone who has been doing this for any length of time knows this business model never lasts. After the Angel Investor money runs out, they either cut pay drastically, stop paying you altogether, or just shut down and don't pay you. Or they do like Examiner did and lock you out in the middle of the night, change the rules that said the work belonged to you, and steal all your work and your original photos.
Look, if you have a ton of social media friends, and you can get them to give you clicks, fine. Ride the horse until it drops, but remember -- it WILL drop, so have another horse ready to ride off on. In other words, don't make this the only egg in your basket.

Been there, done that. Can you say "Bubblews?" Thing was, most of the views came from peers, who didn't click ads, and after the original angel investor money was gone, people stopped getting paid. I've seen this happen over and over again; Examiner, Bright Hub, Mahalo --- should I go on? I've been writing online for 8 years, and this model never works for very long. Never. They always have to drop pay, then they lose their best writers. First, they say you retain copyright to your work, then they change the rules in the middle of the night, lock you out, and steal your work (Mahalo and Examiner both did this).
If you want some fast money while they are still paying, go for it, but don't count on it lasting. Ride that horse until it drops, then get off and have another horse saddled up to take you on ahead.

As for Textbroker, there are people making amazing money there. If you go onto the forums, you will see that teams and direct orders are how to make good money on TB. I used to be on a team that paid .08 a word, and I made a lot of money on it. You can charge whatever you want for direct orders. I use it as a back-up and fill-in site for times when work elsewhere is slow or for days I need $10 more to fill out my quota. It's not a bad place, and $400-500 a month is definitely possible there in time. When I worked it full-time I was pulling in around $500 a week, and I wasn't on any special teams at the time, and I've never had a direct order. It was just choosing easy topics and writing fast.
I'd go with tutoring, though. There are online sites where you can tutor via a skype-like interface and there are also sites like Udemy where you can put up tutorials and have people pay for them.

Free always works. Everybody wants something for free. IMHO, newsletters are the best way to maintain regular contact with subscribers and optins. My favorite newsletter is one for gardening that has recipes, how-tos, and coupons, along with a free something every month, like last month it was a free ebook of all the recipes from last year. You can't just toss out one freebie then spam people to death. The newsletters I sign up for that end up being a spamfest of offers I did not sign up for get unsubscribed and I will never buy from them. I don't believe in spamming people daily because they signed up for a weekly/monthly newsletter. To me, that's just common sense, but a lot of marketers will tell you different.

I agree with this, but you can do it all under one domain if you're careful. I used to have a blog that had four loosely related topics, and each was a subdomain; however, the main site was just basically a landing page with links to the other blogs. I called it a mini blog network, because there was the possibility of always adding more topics. The way I differentiated them was to give them all their own names and themes. At the time, I was doing this on Blogger as bum marketing, and each subdomain was actually a separate blog.
I don't know if that makes sense, but say the name was Joe's Iowa Homestead and the four other blogs were Joe's DIY, Joe's Garden, Joe's Animals and Joe's Great Outdoors. Each blog would have a separate client base and separate marketing, yet they all tie back in to the main blog, which has blurbs with links leading to the specific blogs, plus general posts about homesteading in Iowa. So they are all different, but all connected. I guess you could call these "sister blogs," but I tend to think of sister blogs as being on unrelated topics.

Clickbank can work if you work it right. What I absolutely hated about them was that they were constantly trying to push seminars and programs on you from successful partners. It got so annoying, I blocked them from my email because of so much spam.
You need to have someone who understands contracts figure that out for you. We aren't contract lawyers.

Can you write in AP style? How do you propose to get paid, since most people want to pay by PayPal and you must be 18 to get a PayPal account. I do know teens who have accounts under their parents' names on some content mills and get paid through their PayPal account. Payment is going to be your biggest problem. If you can write, you can find people to buy it. Never accept checks or money orders. Too many scammers out there.
My advice is to find local businesses that have neglected blogs or that could use a blog and sell your services there. That way, you can get checks, have your parents sign for you to open a checking account, and get paid like that. Or they can pay you cash, which has obvious advantages.

I have a skeleton site with links to my blogs and other work I've published online. My portfolio is small, because I specialize, and most of my writing is on my blogs. I only put about 1/3 to 1/2 of the article on the portfolio. That's enough for them to see what I can do, without risking having it stolen.
I can tell you that home improvement, real estate and tech articles sell all year long. Be sure to submit a ton of holiday articles about 2 months before the holiday. They sell well too.

The bigger and more diverse your catalog, the better you will do there. Also, if you specialize, try to write groups of articles to submit on one topic. Clients will buy all of them and put them up one at a time on their blogs.
Yeah, it's all how you work them, and it takes awhile to work your way into good income, but if you plug away at it, you can do it.

HEAR! HEAR! I agree with you 100%. The dems were as complicit in the destruction of working class jobs as the repubs, and it didn't start with NAFTA. It started long before that, when we were buying tons of Japanese steel and putting thousands of small farmers out of business. This goes way back to the Carter administration, and it was a whisper in the wind even before that. We knew it was happening. We did nothing. Instead, we made trade deals like NAFTA, purportedly to make the electronics and auto industry competitive with Japanese imports, when all we had to do was put limits and tariffs on those imports to make them less appealing. Then the other industries said "What about us? I need to be able to get cheaper labor too!" and we let them move to China. Then tech said "Hey, we need cheaper labor," so we let them bring in workers from Asia and displace American workers. Are you aware that Bill Gates threatened to take his company to Canada if we didn't give him more guest worker visas? Did we say "Would you like me to help you pack your smarmy ass and get the fuck out of the country that made you rich?" NO, we changed the laws so that all companies could bring in more visa workers.
Dems let their Wall Street buddies get away with literal grand theft in the very, very, illegal and immoral mortgage debacle, because they needed their money. Plus, if they banks fell, their stock portfolios might be harmed, and they would not have that money to draw on for reelection.
But it's not only the politicians, it's all of us who stood by and became complacent, turned out heads and our backs on the poor, and refused to see what was right in our faces. It was too painful to look. We were not at the breaking point yet.
The Tea Party, which we chose to ignore as "ignorant racists" was formed because those people had had their jobs, their livelihoods, and their dignity stolen from the people who were getting rich off of them. We joked about them as they slowly built themselves up by getting into positions on city and county governments, taking over state legislatures and governor's mansions.
The saddest part is, in all of this, there was an entire generation growing up watching us not give a shit about whether their parents lost their jobs, or they had to move out of the houses they had grown up in and move in to a motel room or live in their cars. Instead, we allowed them to cut more funds for low income housing, putting even more people out into the streets. We didn't care when cuts in food stamps and school lunch and breakfast programs left them hungry and sick and unable to learn. They watched and they grew to hate us all. And we did nothing. We stood by doing nothing while this generation lost parents, family and friends to needless wars, while the military/industrial machine raked in trillions of their parents hard earned money.
These are Trumps's people. I'm one of them, although I didn't vote for him. They are angry and our arrogance and greed is to blame. I have long said that GREED and GREED ALONE is what killed the middle class, not the GOP, just GREED on both sides, across the spectrum.
And we sat back and watched it happen, and turned our heads to homeless families on the street, and the most egregiously arrogant and entitled of us passed laws to punish them for being homeless so we didn't have to have our failures staring us in the face every day.
We are just as complicit as the Republicans, because we made empty promises and did nothing.
I also agree that we have to stop making excuses for Obama. He was a weak president, who did not fight hard enough for us. He could have rallied people to fight congress, but he didn't. He had that power. He could have made a call to arms to get us to where we are now, but he didn't. IMHO, his legacy is one of apathy when the people he was supposed to be leading were suffering.

WRITING.TITLE: What if you are happy with lower wages?
WRITING.TEXT:
I see a lot here and elsewhere about "moving up" and getting better-paying work, but a lot of that comes with a lot more stress. Private clients come with personality conflicts and billing problems, etc.
There are a lot of us who just want a few hundred extra bucks a month, and we're perfectly fine with writing easy articles for low pay on a site where the expectations are low and there is little stress, such a Textbroker or some other mill.
Yet we are constantly berated for bringing down the entire industry. I think that's unfair. Different people have different needs, and not everyone has great ambitions or aspirations. Some of us are older and have absolutely not desire to build a new career.
I'm really sick of being treated like dirt by younger writers who think I'm holding them back. I'm not holding anybody back. There is plenty of well-paying work out there -- go get it -- and leave the rest of us to do what works for our lives.

WRITING.TITLE: Something I found interesting about the debate
WRITING.TEXT:
I don't know if his advisors told him to do this, or what, but Hillary immediately went to talk to the panel members on stage and Trump went to his family. He took a few pictures with people, then he was ushered out. Hillary and Bill remained talking to people and taking pictures for almost 30 minutes after the debate, and had to be made to leave by their security. If you want to know who is in touch with the American people, it's the Clintons, not The Donald.
I'm not crazy about either one of them, but this really struck me.
